questions.text: A 7 yr. old boy presented to the hospital with c/o Pain in his Right hip with restricted movements. Careful examination revealed affected limb in an attitude of Abduction and External Rotation. Blood tests showed normal Hemogram but mildly raised ESR. The next best line of management is :
questions.solution:
• Based on given clinical findings and laboratory findings child is suffering from septic arthritis of hip joint.
  • The first step in treatment of septic arthritis is aspiration of the joint to confirm the diagnosis. If pus is obtained, the joint should be irrigated with saline until the irrigation fluid returns clear. The hip and shoulder should be immediately opened and irrigated after aspiration and joint fluid analysis confirms the diagnosis

CLINICAL FEATURES OF SEPTIC ARTHRITIS OF HIP IN CHILDREN:-

1)rapid development of joint pain and a fever of 100° to 104°F (38° to 40°C). Irritability and malaise may precede the onset of pain.

2)Pseudoparalysis is common in the very young. limitation of motion of the affected joint.

3)The joint is swollen, hot, and globally tender. The affected joint assumes a resting position that maximizes the capsular volume to reduce the tension in the joint. The hip is held flexed abducted and externally rotated. The most comfortable position for most other joints is some degree of flexion.

DIAGNOSIS OF SEPTIC ARTHRITIS:-

  • always aspirate a joint when infection is considered to be a possibility, even when the child does not have the classic severe pain of septic arthritis.
  • Infected joint fluid is cloudy, and mucin is diminished. A drop of fluid rubbed between the thumb and a finger will feel watery and will not string as the opposed fingers are separated
  • The most important studies of the fluid are a culture, Gram stain, white blood cell count, and differential.
  • In blood examination The white blood cell count is generally elevated with an increase in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.

Reference: Herndon WA, Knauer S, Sullivan, Gross RH. Management of Septic Arthritis in Children. J Pediatr Orthop 1986;6:576.

REFERENCE:.Chapmans ORTHOPAEDIC book 3rd EDITION CHAPTER 176 BONE AND JOINT INFECTIONS IN CHILDREN page number 4478

questions.text: A young female presented in Orthopaedic OPD with Bone pains , Tiredness and easy fatiguability . Her X Rays revealed areas of Radiolucency in region of Pubic Rami What is the most probable diagnosis :
questions.solution:
• Xray image shows pseudofracture /milkman's fracture/loosers zone.
  • The characteristic X-ray findings of osteomalacia are Loosers zones named after & mil Looser Swiss surgeon also known as cortical infarctions, Milkman's fractures/ pseudofractures that occur due to incomplete healing of stress fractures by a calcium deficient callus. They appear as thin transverse lucencies, running at right angles to the involved cortex since the indentations are caused by vascular crossings pressing on a soft bone. bone margins may be irregular and sclerotic. Often, they are multiple and symmetrical.
  • Common sites include Lumbar vertebrae pubic and ischial rami, axillary edge of scapula immediately below the glenoid, ribs and clavicle.

Radiographic findings in Osteomalacia

  1. The classical lesion of osteomalacia is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in an otherw ise normal-looking bone. These zones, seen especially in the shaft of long bones and the axillary edge of the scapula and are due to incomplete stress fractures which heal with callus lacking in calcium.
  2. Biconcave codfish vertebraedue to indentation on vertebral bodies by the intervertebral disk
  3. Trefoil or Champagne-glass pelvis

4.Protrusio acetabuli Nontraumatic and spontaneous or pathological fractures of the ribs, pubic rami, femoral neck or the metaphyses above and below' the knee.

Features of secondary hyperparathyroidism characteristically appear in the middle phalanges of the fingers and in severe cases, the so-called brown tumours' are seen in the long bones.

Reference:ApLey s System of Orthopaedics and Fractures, 9 th edition, page number :137

questions.text: Identify disease from the deformity shown in xray image
questions.solution:
• XRAY IMAGE SHOWS PENCIL IN CUP DEFORMITY WHICH IS SEEN IN PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS PATIENT.
  • Radiographic features of psoriatic arthritis include the development of fluffy periosteal new bone at sites of entheseal inflammation, very characteristic of the spondyloarthropathies.
  • Arthritis mutilans: In this rare subtype extreme destruction of the phalanges and MCP joints is seen, giving rise to shortened digits that can be telescoped producing the opera glass deformity and classical 'pencil in cup deformity' on X-rays.

Reference:.Ashman, R. F., Ferguson, P. J., IJdo, J. W., Lawry, G. V., Moore, M. M., Peloso, P. M., Rachow, J. W., Stafford, H. A., Tuetken, R. S., & Vogelgesang, S. A. (2005). Rheumatic Diseases: Diagnosis and Management. In S. L. Weinstein & J. A. Buckwalter (Eds.), Turek's Orthopaedics: Principles and Their Application (6th ed., pp. 151-198). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Xray image shows Cortical radiolucent nidus <1.5 cm(bone within bone appearance)

Osteoid osteoma:-

  • benign bone forming lesion considered to be the most common true benign tumor of the bone
  • Age group:- 2nd-3rddecades
  • Male:female 3:1
  • Lower extremity,long bones,Posterior elements spine ,Diaphyseal/metaphyseal
  • Pain; worse at night
  • XRAY:-Cortical radiolucent nidus <1.5 cm with marked cortical thickening
  • High levels of cyclooxygenases and prostaglandins in the lesion
  • Frequently responds to NSAIDs
  • HISTOLOGY:-Trabeculae surrounded by loose fibrovascular tissue
  • TREATMENT:-NSAIDs, Burr down technique ,Radiofrequency ablation.

Reference:. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :236

questions.text: A 40 years old man, was admitted with FRACTURE shaft femur following a road traffic accident. On 2nd day he became disoriented. He was found to be tachypnoeic, and had conjunctival petechiae. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Based on clinical findings patient is suffering from fat embolism after shaft femur fracture.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 43.

questions.text: A middle aged patient presented in OPD with complaints of pain in wrist around Radial styloid with difficulty in performing activities of daily living. Clinical test demonstrated below to diagnose this condition is :
questions.solution:
• Finkelstein's test:-

Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance

This test is useful in diagnosis of de quervain's tenosynovitis.

  • de QUERVAIN'S TENOSYNOVITIS

This is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process. It results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons (Fig-36.3). On examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process.

Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance (Finkelstein's test). There may be a palpable thickening of the sheath.

TREATMENT In early stage, rest to the wrist in a crepe bandage or a slab, analgesics and ultrasonic radiation may bring relief. In some cases, a local infiltration of hydrocortisone is required. A chronic case may need slitting and excision of a part of the tendon sheath.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 303.

choices.text: Erb's Palsy is an injury to Upper Trunk and has the best prognosis amongst Brachial Plexus Injuries
Klumpke's Palsy is injury to Lower Trunk and may be associated with Horner's Syndrome
Preganglionic lesions have better prognosis than Post Ganglionic Lesions
Histamine Test is used to differentiate between Preganglionic and Postganglionic Lesions

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Brachial Plexus Injury , except :
questions.solution:
CLASSIFICATION OF BRACHIAL PLEXUS INJURIES

  1. Preganglionic versus postganglionic
    1. Preganglionic brachial plexus injuries (BPIs), often referred to as root avulsions, are not repairablebecause the rootlets are avulsed from the spinal cord. They are called preganglionic as the injury has occurred proximal to the dorsal root ganglion.
    2. Postganglionic BPIs occur distal to the dorsal root ganglion and can be repaired by restoring nerve continuity, depending on the mechanism and location of the injury. Mechanisms include lacerations, penetrating injuries, or traction (that results in rupture or stretch injuries)
  • Erb's palsy is injury to upper C5,6 roots of brachial plexus(upper trunk of brachial plexus).
  • Klumpke's palsy is injury to the lower trunk C8 and partially T1(lower trunk of brachial plexus0

Reference-Christensen, T. J., Bishop, A. T., Spinner, R. J., & Shin, A. Y. (2020). Traumatic Brachial Plexus Injuries. In J. R. Lieberman (Ed.), AAOS Comprehensive Orthopaedic Review 3 (3rd ed., pp. 286-301). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

choices.text: Avascular Necrosis of body of Talus

questions.text: Most common complication of Fracture Talus is :
questions.solution:
COMPLICATIONS OF TALUS BONE FRACTURE:-

  1. Avascular necrosis(most common)and non-union: Because of the poor blood supply, after a fracture through the neck, the body of the talus becomes avascular. The avascular fragment fails to unite with rest of the bone and gradually collapses, leading to deformation of the bone, and eventually osteoarthritis of the ankle.
  2. Osteoarthritis: Besides avascular necrosis of the talus, an associated injury to its articular cartilage may lead to osteoarthritis of the ankle. The patient complains of pain and stiffness. Treatment is mostly by physiotherapy and fomentation. In severe cases, an ankle arthrodesis may be needed

Reference : Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 166

questions.text: In the clinical test shown , The Right Hand show's weakness of which muscle and which peripheral nerve palsy is the cause for it ?
questions.solution:
• Adductor pollicis:The patient is asked to grasp a book between the thumb and index finger.
  • Normally, a person will grasp the book firmly with thumb extended, taking full advantage of the adductor pollicis and the first dorsal interosseous muscles. If the ulnar nerve is injured, the adductor pollicis will be paralysed and the patient will hold the book by using the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by median nerve) in place of the adductor. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint of the thumb.

(Fig-10.7). This becomes more pronounced if theexaminer tries to pull the book out while the patient tries to hold it. This sign is known as 'Froment's sign' or the 'book test.

Reference:.maheshwari ortho 5thedition page number 68

choices.text: Cervical Spine is Most commonly involved
Sprains and strains without any obvious fracture

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the Whiplash injury except :
questions.solution:
• Whiplash injury:Cervical spine injury where sudden flexion followed by hyperextension takes place.the acceptable theory is that patient's body is thrown forwards by the car seat while his head flips backwards and then recoils in flexion (hyperextension followed by flexion)

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5thedition page number 86.

questions.text: A 14 yrs old boy presented with painful swelling over Right shoulder . Radiograph of the shoulder showed an Osteolytic area with stippled calcification over proximal humerus epiphysis . Biopsy of lesion revealed an immature fibrous matrix with scattered giant cells. XRays taken revealed : Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
CHONDROBLASTOMA:

  • This benign tumor of immature cartilage cells is one of the few lesions to appear primarily in the epiphysis, usually of the proximal humerus, femur or tibia.
  • The presenting symptom is a constant ache in the joint; the tender spot is actually in the adjacent bone.
  • X-ray shows a rounded, well-demarcated radiolucent area in the epiphysis with no hint of central calcification.

Reference: Apley's System of Orthopaedics, 9th edition, page number 198

questions.text: A young soccer player sustained an injury while playing and presented to the Orthopaedic surgeon with c/o Pain and Instability in the knee joint. The clinical test done below is for identification of which injury pattern :-
questions.solution:
• Function of collateral ligaments: the collateral ligaments are present on either sides of the knee joint. their prime role is to provide stability against a varus or a valgus force. For example as shown in Figure , if a valgus stress (distal to joint, limb moves outwards) is given to the knee, the MCL is stretched and torn and vice versa. So, collateral ligaments basically stabilize the knee joint in the coronal plane (varus stability-LCL and valgus stability-MCL

Reference:.fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra n jain page number :116.

questions.text:
An elderly lady with Severe Inflammatory Arthritis and on long term medications for treatment of Osteoporosis suddenly presented in emergency with pain in thigh with Inability to ambulate. X Rays revealed :

What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• third generation bisphosphonates:-

Ibandronate and zoledronic acid:-

  • Newer long-acting additions that are given as slow IV infusions on monthly and yearly basis respectively. Ibandronate can also be given 150 mg tablet once a month. Long-term use of these drugs (generally over 5 years) has recently caught attention due to special atypical fractures that have been reported in the subtrochanteric area of femur. these are generally transverse insuffciency fractures with thickening of lateral femoral cortex and are associated with slow healing

Reference:fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page no 130

questions.text: Following anterior dislocation of the shoulder, a patient develops weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over the lateral aspect forearm: nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
• MUSCULOCUTANEOUS NERVE PALSY (C5-6) The nerve is a branch of lateral cord of brachial plexus. It is mostly injured by penetrating injuries but seldom in anterior dislocation shoulder or fracture of humerus neck. the nerve supplies coracobrachialis (vestigial), brachialis and biceps brachii.
  • After giving small branch to the humerusand articular branches to the elbow jointit pierces deep fascia and emerges lateral to biceps brachii.It then continues as thelateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.
  • this nerve palsy is generally overlooked as it hardly causes any problems. Sensory loss is ill-defined and even though biceps and brachialis are paralyzed, elbow can still be flexed by a strong brachioradialis.but there will be weakness in flexion.

Reference:fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page number 187-196

questions.text: Snowstorm appearance of knee joint with multiple loose bodies is seen in :
questions.solution:
Synovial Chondromatosis

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a collection of hyaline cartilage nodules within the synovium of large joints. It occurs most frequently in young adults.
  • Patients present with pain, mechanical symptoms, and an enlarging mass. Most patients develop loose fragments of cartilage within the joint, but some patients form an enlarging mass of proliferating chondrocytes in the periarticular tissues.
  • Radiographs reveal speckled calcifications within the joint or in the soft tissues around a joint.
  • The current treatment of synovial chondromatosis includes complete synovectomy and removal of any cartilaginous loose bodies.

Reference: Weber, K. L., & Buckwalter, J. A. (2005). Musculoskeletal Neoplasms and Disorders That Resemble Neoplasms. In S. L. Weinstein & J. A. Buckwalter (Eds.),Turek's Orthopaedics: Principles and Their Application(6th ed., pp. 267-319). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.text:
A 16 yrs old boy presented with c/o mild pain around the knee with difficulty in walking . X rays taken revealed a radiolucent lesion in the metaphyseal area of Proximal tibia

What is the most probable diagnosis :
questions.solution:
• Brodie abscessis an intraosseous abscess related to a focus of subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis. Typically these present in children with unfused epiphyseal plates, more frequently in boys. It has a predilection for ends (metaphysis) of tubular bones, proximal/distal tibial metaphysis is the most common location..

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 177.

choices.text: Most of people are HLAB27 positive
50% of patients may have urinary infection
Bamboo spine may be a radiological feature

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Ankylosing spondylitis EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS/MARIE STRUMPELL DISEASE/BECHTREW'S DISEASE

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic progressive inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy,
  • Most common joint involved is sacroiliac joint > spine .
  • Mc extraarticular manifestation of AS is anterior uveitis.
  • Common in young males of 15-40 years of age M>F(10>1).
  • HLA B27 positive in more than 90% of cases
  • Clinical features-Morning stiffness which is relieved by activity.
  • Most acute spinal fractures in the AS population occur in the cervical spine, particularly at C5-C6 and C6-C7 levels. Vertebral fractures are four times more common while risk of cord damage is 11 times greater in patients with AS.
  • SI side-to-side compression test/ Gaenslen's test/ Pump handle test/Patric test are useful for clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray signs:-Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis is the hallmark of AS.

Bamboo spine

Squaring of vertebrae

Syndesmophytes +

  • Treatment:- NSAIDS and TNF INHIBITORS

Indomethacin is most commonly used NSAIDS

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :290

questions.text: A 60 yrs old gentleman presented with Low back pain , X Rays reveal pathological vertebral fractures. Serum Electrophoresis was positive for M-Band . Whats the likely biochemistry findings?
questions.solution:
Based on history and findings patient is suffering from multiple myeloma

DIAGNOSIS OF MULTIPLE MYELOMA:-

Radiological examination: Characteristic radiological features are as follows (Fig-28.6):

  • Multiple punched out lesions in the skull and other flat bones.
  • Pathological wedge collapse of the vertebra, usually more than one, commonly in the thoracic spine. The pedicles are usually spared
  • Erosions of the borders of the ribs.
  • Blood: Low haemoglobin, high ESR (usually very high), increased total protein, A/G ratio reversed, increased serum calcium, normal alkaline phosphatase.
  • Urine: Bence Jones proteins are found in 30 per cent of cases.
  • Serum electrophoresis: Abnormal spike in the region of gamma globulin (myeloma spike) is present in 90 per cent of cases.
  • Sternal puncture: Myeloma cells may be seen.
  • Bone biopsy from the iliac crest, or a CT guided needle biopsy from the vertebral lesion may show features suggestive of multiple myeloma.
  • Bone scan: This may be required in cases presenting as solitary bone lesion, where lesions at other sites may be detected on a bone scan.
  • Open biopsy: An open biopsy from the lesion may sometimes be required to confirm the diagnosis

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number:245

questions.text: M/C joint involvement in Rheumatoid Arthritis is :
questions.solution:
• Rheumatoid arthritis commonly involves PIP,MCP and WRIST joint bilaterally.
  • Isolated DIP joint involvement is seen In psoriatic arthritis.

Reference:maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 288

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific test for Rheumatoid Arthritis
questions.solution:
• 'Anti CCP antibodies are the most specific blood test fir rheumatoid arthritis (specificity -95%)' - CMDT 09/727
  • Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody testing is particularly useful in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, with high specificity,presence early in the disease process, and ability to identify patients who are likely to have severe disease and irreversible damage.
  • Anti-CCP antibodies have not been found at a significant frequency in other diseases to date, and are more specific than rheumatoid factor for detecting rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) may also be raised in RA.

Reference:manish kumar varshney 1st edition page number:405

questions.text: Which is not a deep heat therapy
questions.solution:
• Infrared therapy
  • Heat therapy is a form of physiotherapy used in many painful conditions eg. arthritis, sprains, muscle spasms etc. It is of 2 types depending on penetration of heat :

- superficial heat therapy

- Deep heat therapy

  • Superficial heat therapy

Only the skin and subcutaneous tissues are heated

Superficial heating modalities do not heat deep tissues because the subcutaneous layer of fat beneath the skin surface acts as a therm m,al insulator and inhibits heat transfer.

Superficial heating modalities include :

1- hot water bottle -

2chemical packs

3warm bath - paraffin wax bath

4- hot packs (eg. Kenny pack) - moist air cabinet

5- hot soaks or compresses -

6infrared lamp

  • Deep heat therapy

Deeper structures (including muscles) are heatedIn general, the transfer of heat is of three types - conduction, convection & conversion (or radiation) [We have read these during our primary schooling]

Whereas superficial heating modalities use all three modes of transfer of heat; deep heating modalities use only conversion or radiation method to heat the deep tissues.

Deep heating modalities are

  1. Short wave diathermy

- heat generated by high frequency alternating current using a short-

wave diathermy emitter.

b.Microwave diathermy

- this uses electromagnetic radiation energy to heat the deep tissues

  1. Ultrasound therapy

- uses high frequency sound energy

Reference:. Maheshwari 5/edition, page number 66; Internet - medicine]

questions.solution:
Plaster casts and their uses Name of the case Use

questions.text: Which of the following is the least useful for diagnosis of Spondylolisthesis?
questions.solution:
X-ray lumbar spine- AP view

Explanation:

  • Although for imaging of spondylolisthesis usually all are done, AP view appears to be least useful of these choices. On AP view, spondylolisthesis can show a sign called Napolean Hat sign. The lateral view is useful in detecting spondylolisthesis; it may demonstrate the pars defect.
  • Spondylolisthesis is forward slip of one vertebrae upon another; so it is best viewed (or seen earliest) in sagittal images of spine i.e. lateral and oblique X-ray of spine and saggital and axial views of CT and MRI

(Reference:Tureks 6/edition,page number 503;

Maheshwarl 3e/p 237; Wolfgang 7/e p 228-29, 206; Sutton 7/edition,page number /66'

choices.text: Central nervous system depression disproportionate to hypoxaemia

questions.text: Which of the following are not included in Gurd's criteria?
questions.solution: Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 43

choices.text: Commonly occurs as a result of twisting force
May be associated with Segond fracture
Lachman test is highly sensitive test for tear

questions.text: All are true about anterior cruciate ligament except?
questions.solution:
LIGAMENTOUS INJURY OF KNEE JOINT -Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

  • Attachments of ACL In tibia immediately behind anterior horn of medial meniscus Pass upwards, backwards and laterally Posterior part of medial surface of lateral femoral condyle
  • It is intra-synovial. Major stabilizer of knee.
  • Its mechanism is to stabilize internal rotation and extension of tibia on femur
  • Limits forward gliding of tibia on femur and limits hyper extension.
  • Significant contribution to lateral stability & limits antero lateral rotation of tibia on femur
  • ACL is most commonly injured with valgus, external (lateral) rotation, hyper extension, deceleration, and rotational knee movements
  • A pop is frequently associated with tearing of a ligament, most commonly the anterior cruciate ligament, or a bone bruise. ACL injuries commonly are associated with sports such as football, hockey, basketball, lacrosse, gymnastics, wrestling, and volleyball.
  • ACL injury rate is 4-6 times higher in females than males in competitive sports. The injury often is associated with immediate pain and an audible "pop". Swelling of the knee is noted within a few hours (acute hemarthrosis). The patient often states that the knee feels too unstable to continue playing and that weightbearing is difficult
  • Typically, full knee extension is limited secondary to pain, effusion, hamstring spasm, and ACL stump impingement. Flexion often is limited by effusion.
  • The Lachman test is the most sensitive examination for acute ACL injuries.

Reference:.manish kumar varshney 1st edition page nUmber:878.

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma is second most common primary malignant bone tumour in children after Osteosarcoma
Fever and weight loss may be present

questions.text: Which of the following is/are true about Ewing sarcoma:
questions.solution:
• Ewing's sarcoma is second most common primary malignant bone tumour in children and adolescent after Osteosarcoma; d. Fever and weight loss may be present
  • Ewing Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma arises from primitive neuroectoderm.

Most common Site: Femur diaphysis > tibia diaphysis

  • Clinical features: Occurs between 10-20 years of age. The patient presents with pain and swelling. History of trauma preceding onset, but it is usually incidental. Often there is an associated fever, in which case it may be confused with osteomyelitis.
  • Treatment This is a highly radio-sensitive tumour melts quickly but recurs. Treatment consists of control of local tumour by radiotherapy , and control of metastasis by chemotherapy.
  • The most common primary malignant bone tumors are osteosarcoma (35%), chondrosarcoma (25%), and Ewing's sarcoma (16%). Less frequently (≤ 5%) occurring tumors are chordoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone, and fibrosarcoma of bone.
  • The most common malignant pediatric bone tumors include osteosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma.

Reference:.maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 243.

choices.text: Curvature of the medial border of the foot
Position of the lateral part of the head of the talus

questions.text: Pirani scoring of CTEV includes all except?
questions.solution:
• PIRANI SCORING The Pirani score is a simple, easy to use tool for assessing the severity of each of the components of a clubfoot.

Pirani Scoring: The components are scored as follows: Each component may score 0, 0.5 or 1

Hind foot contracture score (HCFS):

  1. Posterior crease 2. Empty heel 3. Rigid equinus

Mid foot contracture score (MFCS): 1. Medial crease 2. Curvature of lateral border 3. Position of head of talus

Maximum score is 6 (worse)

reference:fundamentals of ortho by mohindra n jain page number:278

choices.text: Middle path regimen is used in management
Commonly spread by hematogenous route from lung
Lower thoracic and upper lumbar is most common site

questions.text: True about tuberculosis of Spine:
questions.solution:
• Route: Lymphogenous and hematogenous spread has been implicated. in thoracolumbar lesions.
  • Site: Upper thoracic spine ls the most common site of spinal TB in children, the lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae are usually affected in adults
  • Paradiscal is the commonest type. Acute onset paraplegia has a better prognosis
  • Management:
  1. Rest,
  2. Drugs Intensive Phase: HRO (5-6 months); Continuation Phase: HZ (3-4 months) + HR(4-5 months); Prophylactic Phase: HE (4-5 months),
  3. Radiological Follow-up (X-ray, MRI), d. Gradual Mobilisation +/- Spinal braces. management of Abscess/ Sinuses,
  4. Management of Neurological complications
  5. S u r g e r y ( E x cisio n al s u r g e r y D e finitiv e S u r g e r y: In dic a tio n o f S u r g e r y in Pott's spine),
  6. Post-operative care

REFERENCE:maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 186

choices.text: Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra

questions.text: A 70 year old lady got non traumatic compression fracture of L1 vertebra. There is no neurological deficit to this patient. What advise will you give for this Patient:
questions.solution:
• Medical: High protein diet, androgen, estrogen, Vitamin D, fluoride, alendronate, calcitonin, teripratide, denosumab & strontium (both are antiresorptive agent) .
  • Orthopaedic treatment: Exercise & Bracing (ASH brace or Taylor brace)

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :309

questions.text: For assessing the injury of meniscus of knee joint, which of the following test is/are done:
questions.solution:
Tests for Meniscal Injuries -

Menesci :-

1)McMurray test

2)Apley's grinding test :-Appley's grinding test involves placing the patient in the prone position with the knee flexed to 90 degrees. The patient's thigh is then rooted to the examining table with the examiner's knee. The examiner laterally and medially rotates the tibia, combined first with distraction, while noting any excessive movement, restriction or discomfort. The process is then repeated using compression instead of distraction. If rotation plus distraction is more painful or shows increased rotation relative to the normal side, the lesion is most likely to be ligamentous. If the rotation plus compression is more painful or shows decreased rotation relative to the normal side, the lesion is most likely to be a meniscus injury

3)Squat test

4)Thessaly test: This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate at the level of 95% in detecting meniscal tears

reference:manish kumar varshney 1st edition page number :879.

questions.text: Sacroiliac joint involvement in ankylosing spondylitis may be elicited by which of the following clinical signs ?
questions.solution:
• Schober's test is classically used to determine if there is a decrease in lumbar spine range of motion (flexion)

Tests for Sacroiliac Joint Involvement:-

1)Tenderness localized to posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) (as PSIS overlies SI joints)

2)SI side-to-side compression test: The patient is in the side lying position and the examiner's hands are placed over the upper part of the iliac

crest, press- ing toward the floor. The movement causes strain in the SI joint. Positive test is indicated by pain in the SI joint.

3)Gaenslen's test: The patient lies on his or her back, the examiner maximally flexes the hip on the normal side (by pushing the knee towards patient chest) and extends the affected hip (by allowing it to fall over the side of the table). The test is considered positive if the patient complains of pain over the SI joint.

4)Pump handle test : The patient lies supine, the examiner grasps the affected side knee of the patients with one hand and flexes the knee and hip and forces it toward the opposite shoulder across the chest. Pain over involved SI joints indicates a positive test.

5)Patric test/FABER test : The test is performed by keeping the limb flexed, abducted and externally rotated (FABER). If pain is elicited on the ipsilateral side anteriorly, it is suggestive of hip joint pathology of same side. If pain is elicited on the contralateral side posteriorly around the SI joint, it is suggestive of pain arising from SI joint.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :291

questions.text: Arthritis Mutilans is a particularly disabling form of which of the following rheumatological conditions:
questions.solution:
• Presentation is like rheumatoid arthritis - a polyarthritis, distal IP joints of hands involved (unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these are spared) RA factor is negative.
  • Male and Females are equally affected
  • There is a strong genetic predisposition; family history of psoriasis is often present and almost 60% patients who have a concomitant sacroiliitis or spondylitis lesion are positive for HLA-B27.
  • HLA-Cw6 gene is also associated with the disorder.
  • Classic skin lesions and nail lesion help in diagnosis
  • The patient may presents with one of several pattern of joint involvement.(described by Wright and Mall)

1.arthritis of DIP joints

2.asymmetrical oligoarthritis :Most common pattern

3.symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA

4.axial involvement with similar to ankylosing spondylitis

5.arthritis multilans

Pencil in cup appearance or telescoping of phalanges or opera glass deformity seen in : Psoriatic arthropathy

Ivory phalanx seen in: Psoriatic arthropathy.

The drug of choice for psoriatic arthritis-Methotrexate

Treatment is by methotrexate, anti tnf agents ( etanercept and infliximab) ,steroid

Reference:mohindra n Jain 1st edition page number 372

questions.text: A 7 yr. old boy is brought to casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He has swelling and pain on his left elbow. Xray done is given below. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus in which brachial artery is most commonly injured.
  • When there is vascular injury, the patient may complain of paraesthesia or numbness distal to the injury. On examination, the injured limb will be pale or slightly cyanosed, cold, and the pulse will be weak or absent.
  • If a vascular injury is suspected, an angiogram or duplex scan is done immediately. If the test detects vascular injury, emergency treatment must be initiated without much delay.

reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number : 100

questions.text: Which of the following combination of skeletal trauma - nerve injury is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
• Wrist injury is associated with damage to the median nerve, not the anterior interosseous nerve.

Nerve injuries can be associated with closed fractures or open fractures:

  • Closed fractures are less commonly related to nerve injury and spontaneous recovery within 4 months is observed in 90% cases. The nerve is explored if recovery is delayed beyond the expected time, or when nerve conduction studies do not demonstrate any evidence of recovery.
  • Open fractures are more likely to cause the nerve to be completely severed. The nerve is explored and repaired at the time of debridement or during wound closure.

Reference:Maheshwari Ortho 5th edition page number 215

choices.text: 54-year-old man with left sided hemiplegia
60-year-old man with history of MI 3 months back

questions.text: Which of the following patients are unlikely to develop a frozen shoulder?
questions.solution:
• Psoriasis has no association with frozen shoulder.
  • Frozen shoulder is defined as the disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness in the shoulder joint which spontaneously resolves after around 18 months.

Associated conditions include:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cervical disc disease
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Prolonged immobilization
  • Stroke or myocardial infarction

Reference:maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number : 300.

choices.text: Both anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee on the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur on gently pulling the upper end of the tibia. However, the forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur appears normal. What is the structure most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario of a direct anterior blow to the knees such as dashboard injury and excessive backward movement in the posterior drawer test is suggestive of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.
  • The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function with just appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation, without the need for surgical intervention.
  • On performing the anterior drawer test, the normal forward gliding movement of the tibia in relation to femoral condyles is suggestive of apparently normal anterior cruciate ligaments.

Dashboard injury can also lead to

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

The image below is an MRI of the knee joint, and the arrow shows the posterior cruciate ligament.

reference:: Maheshwari, 5th edition, page number : 148-149

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient came with complaints of backache. On radiography, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is hemangioma. The radiograph shows the vertebral body depicting vertical striations, giving a corduroy appearance.
  • Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. The atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion.
  • Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.
  • Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance. On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.
  • Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas.
  • The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right)

Option A: Eosinophilic granuloma is a benign lesion of the vertebral body with a classic radiographic finding of vertebra plana, as shown below.

REFERENCE:,fundamentals of ortho by mohindra n jain page number : 261

Option C: Paget disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance, as shown below.

Option D: Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder that is characterized by a low bone mass and defects in bone structure, thus rendering the bone unusually fragile and at greater risk of fracture compared to a person of the same age, sex, and race. On a vertebral radiograph, there is a biconcave appearance of the vertebra known as the codfish vertebra, as shown below.

reference:,fundamentals of ortho by mohindra n jain page number :261

questions.text: A diabetic patient reports that his index finger initially remains bent, but with further effort, it suddenly straightens with a snap. On examination, a tender nodule can be felt in front of the metacarpophalangeal joint. The suspected deformity is called
questions.solution:
• The given findings are suggestive of the trigger finger, and it is caused by the involvement of the flexor tendon.
  • Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect.
  • The nodule can be trapped behind the A1 pulley, leading to a locking of the finger in flexion. Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed.

Other options:

  • Option A: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the distal interphalangeal joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g. a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
  • Option C: Bouchard nodes are the osteophytes or bony lumps present in the proximal interphalangeal joints. These are seen in patients with osteoarthritis.
  • Option D: Dupuytren's contracture is proliferating fibroplasia involving palmar aponeurosis. It causes flexion deformity of one or more fingers as a result of abnormal thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis. It is more common in males, and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho, 5thedition, page number:303

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to the emergency department with left wrist pain following a fall. On examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. His x-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of Bennett fracture.
  • Bennett fracture is an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the base of the first metacarpal from the rest of the first metacarpal. It is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb.
  • The fracture is oblique and extends into the carpometacarpal joint. The strong pull of the abductor pollicis longs tendon that remains attached to the shaft of the metacarpal makes the fracture very unstable. X-ray shows a small triangle fragment remained in contact with the medial edge of the
  • Plaster is applied with a felt pad over the fracture, and the first metacarpal is held in abduction and extension by flexing the MCP joint. Surgical fixation is done by passing a K-wire across the metacarpal base unto the carpus.

Other options:

  • Option B: Rolando fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with aT or Y configuration. The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.
  • While both Bennett and Rolando fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando fracture is a comminuted fracture producing 3 parts, whereas Bennett fracture is a 2 piece fracture.

The X-ray shown below depicts a Rolando fracture.

Option C: Boxer fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal, as shown below.

Option D: Barton fracture is a split of the volar edge of the distal radius, as shown below.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho, 5th edition, page number :366

questions.text: Which is the classification system used for the fracture shown in the x-ray given below?
questions.solution:
• The given image is of the fracture of the proximal humerus. The most widely accepted classification is the Neer classification, which involves 4 major segments in injuries:

Head of humerus

Greater tuberosity

Lesser tuberosity

Shaft of humerus

  • Neer classification distinguishes between the number of displaced fragments, with displacement defined as greater than 45 degrees of angulation or 1 cm of separation.

Other options

Option A: The Schatzker classification is a method of classifying tibial plateau fractures.

Option B: The Ideberg classification is a method of classification of intra-articular glenoid fossa fractures.

Option D: The Garland classification is a method of classification of supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho, 5th edition, page number 92

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
The partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon is responsible for painful arc syndrome rather than a complete tear.

Painful arc syndrome is also known as impingement syndrome. It is a clinical syndrome in which there is a pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range (between 60-120 degrees) of shoulder abduction.

This arises because of the repetitive rubbing of the supraspinatus tendon under the coracoacromial arch.

Causes include:

  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity
  • Subacromial bursitis

Important tests for impingement are:

  • Painful arc test
  • Hawkin-Kennedy's test
  • Neer's impingement sign
  • Jobe's test

Reference:Maheshwari ortho, 5th edition, page number:304

questions.text: Loss of nerve conduction with intact continuity of the nerve, following a closed fracture, is known as
questions.solution:
• As the question mentions loss of conduction following a closed fracture, axonomesis would be the best answer among the given options.
  • Axonomesis (axonal interruption): There is loss of conduction, but the continuity of the nerve is maintained and the neural tubes are intact.
  • It occurs following trauma- such as fractures and dislocations.
  • There is disruption of the axon i.e., the continuity of the axon is broken. But the endoneurium and perineurium are intact, maintaining the continuity of the nerve.
  • As the axon is severed, there is loss of conduction (unlike the slowing of conduction as seen in neurapraxia).
  • It is followed by Wallerian degeneration of the disrupted axon, and then by axonal regeneration.
  • Wallerian degeneration: Distal to the lesion, axons disintegrate and are resorbed by phagocytes
  • Axonal regeneration- numerous fine unmyelinated fibers grow from the proximal stumps and reach the endoneurial tubes

Other options:

  • Neurapraxia: Reversible physiological nerve conduction block causing some loss of sensation and muscle power, followed by spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks.

It occurs following prolonged compression, as in Saturday night palsy, and crutch palsy.

It leads to segmental demyelination but the axon is intact.

As the axon is intact, nerve conduction occurs but is slowed down because of the loss of myelin. Hence, it is also known as physiological conduction block.

It is followed by the regeneration of the myelin.

  • Transient ischemia: Acute nerve compression causing transient endoneurial anoxia. Recovery occurs within a few minutes. It occurs following day to day activities like sitting cross-legged, kneeling down, etc.
  • Neurotmesis: Division of the nerve trunk usually associated with open wounds.

The endoneurial tubes are destroyed and the scar tissue prevents the regenerating axons from entering the distal segment and reaching their target organs.

The regenerating fibers mingle with proliferating Schwann cells and fibroblasts forming a neuroma at the site of injury.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho, 5th edition, page number:63

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lower backache and stiffness which has been gradually progressive for the past 10 years. His symptoms are more severe in the early morning and improve on exercise. The x-ray image shows this characteristic finding.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. There is a single central radiodense line related to the ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments known as dagger sign.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

Sacro-iliac joints:

  • Cardinal sign/earliest sign- erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
  • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint

Vertebral changes:

  • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (squaring)
  • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges)
  • between adiacent vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :290

questions.text: All of the following features are due to periosteal reaction except
questions.solution:
• Cotton wool (popcorn/breadcrumb) appearance is due to lvtic lesion with calcification. It is seen in chondrosarcoma.
  • Periosteal reaction:

Codman's triangle is a reactive bone formation parallel to the bone and is triangular. It is seen in osteosarcoma

Hair-on-end appearance is also seen in osteosarcoma.

Onion-peel appearance is found in Ewing's sarcoma.

Tooth sign: Periosteal reaction of the anterior patellar surface

The given x-ray image shows cotton wool appearance in chondrosarcoma:

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number :246

questions.text: According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, which of the following is a part of the middle column?
questions.solution:
Posterior longitudinal ligament is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability:

Anterior column:

  • Anterior half of the vertebral body
  • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
  • Anterior longitudinal ligament

Middle column:

  • Posterior half of the vertebral body
  • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
  • Posterior longitudinal ligament

Posterior column:

  • Pedicles
  • Facet joints
  • Posterior bony arch
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Supraspinous ligament

The fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries i.e. there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage of the neural tissues.

The given image shows the three spinal columns:

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number:266

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presents with high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals swelling of the knee joint and tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. All of the following factors contribute to metaphyseal involvement in this infection, except
questions.solution:
The complaints of fever, pain, and swelling of the knee following an episode of sore throat along with raised ESR, CRP, and leucocytosis in a child point to a diagnosis of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. A faint extracortical line on X-ray due to periosteal new bone formation is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis. Slow growth is not a reason for metaphyseal involvement in this infection.

Osteomyelitis in children usually starts in the vascular metaphysis of a long bone and the following local factors are important causes that contribute to this:

  • The hairpin bend of the metaphyseal vessels slows down the circulation and allows organisms to escape out of the vessel. (Option A)
  • Metaphyseal hemorrhage occur due to microscopic trauma and the clot so formed acts as an excellent culture media for the bacteria to grow. (Option B)
  • Defective phagocytosis is present. WBCs remove the debris of the decalcification occurring in the growth process and their function of eliminating the offending organism is slightly impaired. (Option C)
  • The rapid growth of the metaphyseal cells makes them susceptible to the action of bacterial toxins as they are immature. (Option D)
  • Vasospasm arrests further bleeding from the traumatized vessels but cause anoxia and failure of antibiotics and other defense cells from reaching the area.

Refernce: maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number:168

choices.text: Transfer of tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: A male patient presented with a knee dislocation. The nerve at the level of the fibular neck is injured. All of the following can be used for the treatment of this condition, except
questions.solution:
• The common peroneal nerve is generally injured at the level of the fibular neck. It leads to a foot drop. Bohler-Braun splint is used in the fracture of the femur. It is an immobilizer frame, which is not suitable for transportation and hence cannot be used for nerve injuries.
  • The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula
  • Knee dislocations.
  • Toe-raising splint and ankle-foot orthosis (FO) brace are used for conservative treatment. Reconstructive procedures like transfer of the tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot can be done.
  • The AFO brace is shown in the image below.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number:333

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. He is diagnosed with osteoclastoma after evaluation. What is the characteristic x-ray appearance seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The characteristic X-ray appearance seen in osteoclastoma or giant cell tumors is a soap bubble appearance. The other characteristic x-ray appearances are seen in the following conditions:

  • Onion-peel appearance - Ewing's sarcoma (Option A)
  • Sunburst (sunray) appearance - Osteosarcoma (Option B)
  • Multiple punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma (Option D)

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment:

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting.
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number:244

questions.text:
A 33 year-old male motorcyclist presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with significant left hip pain and inability to bear weight. The affected leg is in the position as shown in the below image.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the above image, the affected leg is in the state of flexion, abduction and external rotation (FABER). Hence the most likely diagnosis is anterior dislocation of the hip.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as superior and inferior. When seen from the side:

  • If the femoral head lies anteriorly it is called as the superior (pubic) type
  • If the femoral head lies in the groin it is called as the inferior (obturator) type

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number : 131

choices.text: The femoral head can be felt in the groin
Hip movements are found to be decreased
The femoral head appears smaller than unaffected side in the radiograph

questions.text: A 25-year-old man undergoes a road traffic accident. He presents to the casualty with his hip in flexion, abduction and external rotation. There seems to be an apparent lengthening of the limb. With regard to the current scenario, which of the following statements may not be true?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip. The femoral head appears larger than the unaffected contralateral side in the anteroposterior view of the radiograph.

  • In the inferior type of anterior dislocation, the femoral head is felt in the groin.
  • In extremely high energy injuries, the femoral vessels can be injured.

Below radiograph shows the anterior hip dislocation. The limb is abducted and the femoral head is displaced inferiorly.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 131

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with pain and swelling of elbow. He had a past history of fracture of radial head which was surgically treated. X-ray done is given below. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of myositis ossificans which is a complication of fracture. Recurrence of this condition can be prevented by indomethacin and radiotherapy.
  • Myositis ossificans is defined as ectopic benign pathological bone formation. It is most commonly seen after dislocation of elbow or a blow to brachialis, deltoid or quadriceps. The patient presents with gross restriction of range of movements and should be advised not to massage the site as it promotes ossification.
  • Treatment involves joint rest in the position of function until the pain subsides, followed by gentle movements. After a few months if the pain and restriction still persist then the bony mass is excised.
  • The X-ray given below shows myositis ossificans.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page number 102 -105
